did.head: Overview
did.physloc: Special Collections and University Archives materials are stored offsite and must be paged 36-48 hours in advance. For more information on paging collections, see the department's website: http://library.stanford.edu/spc.

repository.label: Repository:

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Russsell and Sigurd Varian were co-inventors, with William W. Hansen, of the klystron and rhumbatron and co-founders of Varian Associates. Educated at Stanford University, physicist and inventor Russell Varian began his career with Philo Farnsworth on early television technology and with Humble Oil on instrumentation for oil exploration. In 1935, he returned to Stanford. Joined by his brother, Sigurd, a pilot with Pan American Airlines, he began work on microwave technology as a research assistant with Professor William Hansen. The klystron patent brought both financial gain to the University and the attention of federal research agencies, while leading to the formation of Varian Associates, one of California's first Silicon Valley companies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Varian papers span almost a hundred years of creative and independent thinking, from early manuscripts of poetry by John O. Varian, to the creation and growth of Varian Associates. In addition to original research notebooks and correspondence regarding the klystron, the papers of Russell and Sigurd Varian include materials on numerous other inventions and ideas from Russell's work for Philo Farnsworth and Humble Oil as well as the brothers' years at Stanford and at Varian Associates. Unpublished short stories by Sigurd reveal his sense of humor as well as the adventure and danger of his career as a pilot in Mexico and Central America.

The Varian Papers also contain correspondence, diaries, and writings of other family members including Dorothy Varian, Agnes Dickson Varian, Aileen Dickson Harrison, and Eric Varian. The letters and diaries of Agnes Dickson Varian pertain to family and community life in Palo Alto and Halcyon, California; Dorothy Varian's papers include her research files used to prepare her biography of Russell and Sigurd Varian as well as correspondence, talks, and other papers pertaining to environmental issues. There is also a series containing photographs documenting the family, Varian Associates, and the history of the klystron.

scopecontent.p: Professional and personal correspondence, research notebooks, scientific writings and publications, speeches, patent records, personal writings, and biographical materials.

bioghist.p: Earned his BA in physics at Stanford in 1925 and his MA in 1927, fellow student was Bill Hansen. He went to work for Farnsworth Television Laboratory, producing at least 11 patentable devices. In 1933 he returned to Stanford to continue his graduate work in physics.

1898 Born 1903 Family moved to Palo Alto 1914 family moved to Halcyon, CA 1919 started at Stanford 1925 BA 1927 MA 1935- graduate work 1935 sets up laboratory in Halcyon with Sig and Eric 1937 Feb. return to Stanford to work on radar 1937 Aug. 19 & 21 first oscillating klystron tests 1939, Jan. first successful test of Klystron [or invention of klystron announced to public] 1940 fall work for Sperry Gyroscope 1946 returned to Stanford 1948 founding of Varian Associates 1950 move of Varian Associates to Stanford Industrial Park 1959 died

scopecontent.p: Professional and personal correspondence, research notes and subject files, scientific writings, patent records, autobiographical writings and short stories, and biographical materials.

bioghist.p: Worked for California Edison after graduating from high school and soon became entranced by flying. He became a pilot 1923, flew in air meets and in air stunts during county fairs. He took a job as a flying serviceman for Southern Sierras Power Company. A prolonged bout of tuberculosis sidelined him for a year in 1928; after that he was employed by Pan American as a pilot on their Mexican and Central American routes.
Sigurd and Russell had always collaborated on their scientific and technical ideas, with Sigurd often the one to design and build the apparatus.

1901 Born in Syracuse, NY 1903 Family moved to Palo Alto 1914 family moved to Halcyon, CA 1923 became a pilot 1929 Married Winifred Hogg 1929-35 flight captain for Pan American Airways 1937 Aug. 19 & 21 first successful tests of oscillating klystron 1939, Jan. invention of klystron announced to public 1940 fall work for Sperry Gyroscope 1948 founding of Varian Associates 1961 died in plane crash in Mexico

Russell and Sigurd F. Varian were the two oldest sons of John O. Varian and Agnes Dickson Varian. John O. Varian, an Irish-born poet and playwright, moved the family from New York to Palo Alto, California in 1903. Although the familyâs economic earnings were modest, their home was a gathering place for writers, musicians, and social reformers. In 1914, the family moved again to Halcyon, California, where John and Agnes Varian operated a general store and post office. Russell Varian, born in 1898, began his undergraduate career at Stanford University in 1919, earning his B.A. in physics in 1925 and his M.A. in 1927. He worked with Philo Farnsworth on early television technology and with Humble Oil on instrumentation for oil exploration before returning to Stanford in 1935 to continue his graduate work in physics.

Sigurd F. Varian, born in 1901, worked for California Edison after graduating from high school. He soon became entranced by flying. He became a pilot in 1923, flying in air meets and doing air stunts during county fairs. He took a job as a flying serviceman for Southern Sierras Power Company. A prolonged bout of tuberculosis sidelined him for a year in 1928; in 1929 he was employed by Pan American as a pilot on their Mexican and Central American routes.

Sigurd and Russell had always collaborated on their scientific and technical ideas, with Sigurd often the one to design and build the apparatus. In 1935 Sigurd, Russell and their brother Eric started their own laboratory in Halcyon.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, research files, and interviews pertaining to her biography of Russell and Sigurd Varian; correspondence, text of talks, articles, and other papers pertaining to Castle Rock Park, Varian genealogy, Varian Associates, and environmental issues.

bioghist.p: Dorothy Varian earned her A.B. in economics and business administration at the U of C at Berkeley in 1928. She pursued a career in advertising in the Bay Area prior to her marriage to Russell Varian in 1947, whom she had met on a Sierra Club trip. She served on the initial Board of Directors of Varian Associates and was its treasurer until 1951.

Mrs. Varian was an active conservationist; with colleagues Doris Leonard and George Collins, she cofounded Conservation Associates in 1960. Their fundraising efforts helped create the Alaska wildlife Range, Point Reyes National Seashore, and Montana de Oro State Park. The Association also worked with the Varian Foundation and Sempervirens Fund to expand the Castle Rock State Park, originally envisioned by Russell Varian.
